title: Energy conservation block in loop gets launched

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A block of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> is held against a compressed spring that has a spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. When released, the block travels with negligible friction along a track that has both straight sections and curved sections as shown. The block loses contact with the spring when it reaches position <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, then travels along a straight section before reaching a circular loop of radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, where <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> is much larger than the size of the block. The block maintains contact with the loop as it travels around the circle. After leaving the loop, the block continues along another straight section before encountering a quarter-circle track section with the same radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. As indicated, position <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is located at the top of the loop, and position <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> is located at the end of the quarter-circle section. (a) When the block reaches position <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, the normal force exerted on the block by the track is equal in magnitude to the gravitational force exerted on the block.Express your answers to parts (a)(i) and (a)(ii) in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.i. Derive an expression for the speed of the block at position <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.
